doc.field: The German government is extending DM 2 million in aid to Turkey to be used in recent earthquake areas. A team of the ministry for development aid will coordinate the application in the affected region.
Wage scale agreement for North Rhine-Westphalia's retail trade

The wage quarrel in North Rhine Westphalia's retail trade was ended by a new agreement between unions and employers. The agreement provides for a 2.1% raise in wages effective as of June 1st, 1998. In addition, low income employees will get raises above the average. Apprentices will receive an additional DM 12 per month during the first 2 years of apprenticeship and DM 15 during the third year. It was agreed that no increases will be paid for April and May. The agreement in Germany's largest tariff region has a validity of 12 months. Leaderships of unions and employers have a July 13th deadline to decide on sanctioning this compromise solution. The outcome of the wage talks is on a level with agreements in other regions.
Telekom launches local tariff calls for D1-Net

The Deutsche Telekom is offering local tariffs in its D1-Net as of late August. Customers can make a choice of an area where they will pay a daytime rate of DM .68 instead of DM 1.89 a minute. In densely populated regions this will be the area covered by a 4-digit area code; in rural areas the first 4 digits will identify a local tariff region. The new tariffs are valid for interconnection with the fixed net.

A German hooligan who had attacked and injured a Brazilian TV-cameraman during the Lens world championship match on June 21st was arrested by Kaiserslautern police today. During the interrogation he confessed. He had been recognized by policemen from a TV newscast.
Tennis: Kiefer drops out in Wimbledon

For the first time in 17 years there will be no German players in Wimbledon's eighth finals. The last of an original number of 17 German tennis pros, Nikolas Kiefer, was beaten by Richard Krajizek 4:6, 6:7 and 6:7.
